On Sun, Jun 15, 2008 at 3:37 AM, Mark Levison <mlevison@...> wrote:
> We agree that the logging itself doesn't belong in JUnit. But I think
> that the current Assertions make logging impossible without resorting
> to byte code injection, AOP or similar techniques with which I'm not
> familiar.
>

I have not felt that I needed logging in my testcases but I did try to
extract information from them to use bumblebee-generated
documentation. I found that when using the new assertThat-syntax you
can replace the existing assertThat-method with your own and still
have all the same matchers at your disposal. So from JUnit 4.4 it is
quite easy to extend JUnit to log assertions should you want that as
long as you stick to the assertThat(actual, matcher) style.

Does that sound like a good enough solution?
/J
